addressleaf.section:
To S
r
Rob. Cecyll Mar 16 1592.

page.lettertext:
fol.41r
To S
r
R. Cecil
May it please your H. to be advertised,
t
through
e slackn[ess of .]
messenger, I had not
t
l
re
w
c
your H. writte unto me
e 10 of [.]
e 14 of this moneth: whereinclosed I had a copie of her
Hig
es
[lettre to the]
States,
but having nothing els to say fr
o
her M
tie
unto th
e
, [.]
of themselves using speeches of replie, I have nothing up[.]
signifie further. They are greatly busied at this p
nt
, to surprise [
Gertru]
denbergh
, w
c
I thinke they will attempt w
t
in 3 or 4 daies, and th[.]
hope
happe
to be repulsed, yet they purpose to goe forward and besiege [.]
The number there in garrison, w
c
are Burgonions for
e most, and [.]
ported above 600 are unprovided of powder, victuall, wodde, and other [neces]
saries, and ill affected to their gouverno
r
Mons
r
Waterdicke
. [The]
two advenues to
e towne, w
c
they hope up
o
e soddaine to be able to blocke
howsoever
e Enemie shall come
vided w
t
forces to levie
e siege, to[.]
allwaies at hand
e towne of
Breda
for a ready retraite. [.]
doe make full acco
u
t to bring unto
e siege, about 1500 horse, and [.]
foote. The
Councell of estate
doth remaine at
e Hage, [pro]
posing as yet, to be p
nt
at
e siege. We are advertis[ed from]
Brussels
,
t
Co
u
t Mansfeld
e father doeth grow very odiou[s .]
the Martial people of those places (w
c
are also full of fo[.]
dislikes, and disorders) and giveth ill satisfacti
o
to all sor[.]
suitours: especially of late, to those of
Dunkerke,
Grave,
[and]
Boisleduc.
In effect they write from thense,
t
e Spaniard[s]
designe, if
e worst come unto th
e
, is onely to holde
e towne [.]
Castels of
Gand,
Andwerp,
and Brussels, w
t
Mastricht,
[.]
Namurs,
a
d to make litle reckning of leesing
e rest. [It is]
also writt
e
am
o
g other occurr
e
ces,
t
Mons
r
Baligny
e Govern[or of]
C
a
bray
hath receaved of late 6000 crownes of
e
Kinge
[of
Spain]
for paiem
t
of
e garrison there. If there be any mate[r in]
this l
re
worth
e imparting to her Hig
es
I doe humbly be[seech]
you, to vouchesafe me
e favour, and to excuse me in like [maner]
unto my
L. T
re
r
, having nothing but this to signifie unto [.]
It re
q
reth
e length of an other l
re
, to thanke your H. [.]
and to request you a freshe about my licence to returne. [.]
t
I c
a
say, doth tend to this effect, That
e greatest griefe
t
I [have]
is
e stay of her M
tie
in graunting my licence, and yet I have no gre[.]
th
e
her M
ts
good liking to continue me heere. And when I take [.]
solace, of
t
w
c
is
e cause of my greatest sorrowe, your H. may c
o
jec[ture]
t
I am not at mine ease. I c
a
not signifie more unto you, [.]
declaring
e needes of my privat estate, th
e
I have done heeretofore
w
c
I beseeche you to remember, to urge w
t
all your favour, and to accept
in
t
behalf, my most thankfull acknowledgm
e
t of your honorable ende
vours.
Wherew
t
I take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage. Ma
r
16 1592.
